newsitem.title: INDIA: India budget can be passed after test vote-Speaker.
newsitem.headline: India budget can be passed after test vote-Speaker.

text.p: The speaker of India's lower house of parliament, P.A. Sangma, said on Wednesday that the budget for 1997/98 (April-March) can be passed even if the government fails to win a vote of confidence next week.
"There is a precedent that even after the resignation of the government, the budget has been taken up," Sangma told reporters at Parliament House.

The market-friendly budget presented on February 28 was suddenly called into question on Sunday after the Congress party withdrew its make-or-break support for Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's United Front coalition.
Deve Gowda will seek a confidence vote on April 11, Parliamentary Affairs Minister Srikanta Jena said earlier on Wednesday.

Deve Gowda's United Front coalition leaders said on Tuesday that they were exploring the possibility of trying to push the path-breaking budget, which would slash corporate and personal tax rates, through parliament before the trust vote.
Sangma said it was up to government to decide when the budget would be put to a vote in parliament.
"No. It is for the government to decide," Sangma said, when asked if he was trying to call a meeting of political parties to find ways to approve the budget.
Finance Minister P. Chidambaram has talked with Sangma on telephone and said coalition leaders were discussing ways to get the budget approved in parliament, the house speaker said.
"I do not foresee any crisis on the budget," Sangma said, adding that leaders of all political parties were responsible.
Many lawmakers have met Sangma and expressed concern over the fate of the budget, he said.
"Now that the vote on account has been passed which will be valid up to end-May, the budget has to be passed before the end of May unless another vote on account is passed," Sangma said.
Last month the lower house approved a bill, called a vote on account, providing for continued appropriation of money to fund government programmes until the 1997/98 (April-March) budget was approved.
